description:
Ray is a young inventor living in the U.K. in the middle of the 19th century. Shortly before the first ever Great Exhibition, a marvelous invention called the "Steam Ball," behind which a menacing power is hidden, arrives at his door from his grandfather Lloid in the U.S. Meanwhile the nefarious O'Hara Foundation has sent men to aquire the Steam Ball so that they can use its power towards their own illicit ends.

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Steampunk
tags.description: Prominently features technology and designs inspired by 19th-century industrial steam-powered machinery.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Ojou-sama
tags.description: Features a wealthy, high-class, oftentimes stuck up and demanding female character.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

node.description: Ken Munekata is a corporate executive and businessman. He was born in Sasebo, a city in Nagasaki Prefecture.

Kawashiro Kazumi is the president & CEO of Bandai Visual. He graduated from Sophia University - a private university in Japan famous for its international climate. In April of 1982, a month after graduation, he started working at Canyon Records. In July of 1989 he joined Bandai and in April of 1994 he was transferred to Bandai Visual of which he became the president of in May of 2003. In 2010, he was succeeded by Ooshita Satoshi, although Kawashiro remained in the company as the vice-president. In April 2012, he was again appointed the president of Bandai Visual.

(Source: AniDB)
Kunikatsu Kondou is a film and TV producer. As of 2017, he has been working for Telepack, a TV programme production company owned by TBS and Dentsu. In the past, he worked for TBS.

Takayuki Yoshii is a producer and a former chairman and CEO of studio Sunrise. After 14 years of serving as president, Yoshii became the chairman on April 25, 2008, with former managing director Uchida Kenji becoming the fifth president in the company's history.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1399705447058137088)

Affiliated with [Bandai Visual](https://anilist.co/studio/23/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大友克洋) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuhiro_Otomo) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/oyaji_shu)

Best-known as the creator of the manga series [Akira](https://anilist.co/manga/30664/), and its 1988 [film adaptation](https://anilist.co/anime/47/).

While he was in high school he was fascinated with movies, often taking a three-hour train ride during school holidays just to see them. After having graduated high school in 1973, he left Miyagi, heading to Tokyo with the hopes of becoming a mangaka. He made his debut later on the same year with a manga adaptation of Prosper Mérimée's short novel Mateo Falcone, titled A Gun Report. In 1979, after writing multiple short-stories for the magazine Action, Ootomo created his first science-fiction work, titled Fireball. Although the manga was never completed, it is regarded as a milestone in Ootomo's career, containing many of the same themes he would later explore in [Doumu](https://anilist.co/manga/31215/), which began serialization in January 1980 and ran for two years until completed.

In 1982, Ootomo made his anime debut as character designer on [Harmagedon](https://anilist.co/anime/1626/). After this Ootomo began working on Akira, which would become his most acclaimed and famous work. The manga took eight years to complete and would eventually culminate in 2000 pages of artwork.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大友克洋) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katsuhiro_Otomo) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/oyaji_shu)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/126575633)
Veteran animator specialized in effects animation.

Steve Jablonsky (born October 9, 1970) is an American music composer for film, television and video games. He has composed the soundtracks to the movies The Texas Chainsaw Massacre (2003), Steamboy (2004), The Island (2005), Transformers (2007), D-War (2007) and Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen (2009).    He has composed the sountracks to the video games Metal Gear Solid 2 (2001), Gears of War 2 (2008), Command & Conquer 3: Kane's Wrath (2008), The Sims 3 (2009), Prince of Persia: The Forgotten Sands (2010), Gears of War 3 (2011) and the Transformers games among others.    Jablonsky's Metal Gear Solid 2 soundtrack won the E3 award for 'Best Original Score' and he has won two BMI Film Music Award's for both The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and Transformers.
Originating from [Oh! Production](https://anilist.co/studio/234/). Mainly works in theatrical animations.

Born: September 29, 1965

Sound director and designer.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/eguchi_1203)

_Note: Not to be confused with the famous illustrator [Hisashi Eguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/113237/)._
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/村井さだゆき)

Takagi Shinji is an anime director, animation and CG supervisor working for Production I.G. Aside from being involved in several notable I.G feature films he was also director of the animation staff for several Sakura Taisen games.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Horidesk) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/horidesk/) | [Website](http://horidesk.m78.com)

Originating from Studio Pokke, currently freelance.

Pioneered the cel shaded, expressive look that distinguishes [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/)'s CG work.
